												First off, this is my favorite game of all time. I've had it for a long time in physical format, but due to it's drm it's unplayable on modern systems, so I bought the steam version. I was a bit afraid of how it would run based on some of the reviews that have reported problems, so I was ready to issue a steam refund just in case.So here's the score: this game is flawless. I've seen some negative reviews and let me address some of them. First of all, all those who say it's unplayable with keyboard and mouse are idiots, no two ways about it. You control your speed via the mouse wheel. It's that simple. Besides, you can customize the controls to your heart's content. Second off, no, it doesn't have checkpoints. And you know why? Because it doesn't need them! It has a quicksave function! I swear, some people...How about the game itself? It's the best stealth game of all time. Period. You have full feedback of how much noise you make and how much noise is in the environment, how visible you are, you get a lot of tools for dispatching or distracting your enemies, you have nightvision, thermal vision and even "electric" vision that let's you see objects that use electricity (useful when completing some of the objectives). It has a fairly intelligent AI. The game is a bit too easy if you just kill everyone in my opinion but it's damn fun. If you like the suspense of stealth, look no further.The graphics still hold up to this day in my opinion. Some of the round objects are a bit angular, but it doesn't take me out of the experience, and the textures still look great. There's also a surprising ammount of color that, compared to a lot of modern games, are a breath of fresh air. The sound design is superb and the soundtrack just ups the suspense. The music is low key and dynamic, changing to the gameplay.Some of the writing is a bit too convoluted for me. Don't get me wrong, it's good, but it's hard to follow, especially for the first time playing. You really have to invest your brain into the story or you'll get lost in it.All in all, if you even remotely like stealth games don't you dare miss out on this one.

												Rather than asking for twitch reflexes and an emphasis on mass murder, Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory asks the player to be aware. This is not a game where the locales are merely canvases to spill blood - every inch of ever level is laden with multiple ways to progress through the mission. Shadows, vents, windows, pipes and balconies which can be hung off of... not only are you given a wide array of ways to avoid enemy detection, but these assets can be used to silently (and stylishly) take out enemies. Not only does the environment give an incredible amount of replay-friendly playstyle options, but it also reeks of atmosphere and immersion in a way that I've never seen in a video game since. Not only are the dark, glistening graphics and ambient sounds well-done, but the moody soundtrack by Amon Tobin serves as the syrupy glaze to the atmospheric pancake. Meanwhile, the level design has a realistic feel to it, as though every hallway that you enter could be a real place.Overall, Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is a gameplay masterpeice and a technical marvel that still impresses today, over ten years after its release. Almost every aspect has such a great level of polish that, despite the game's relatively niche genre, I reccomend this game to everyone who has ever picked up a game controller.

												Let me specify something- for 8 years, this has been my favorite game of all time. I played the absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the xbox version of it- and while it may feel more suited to a controller, it can be handled just as well on a mouse and keyboard (though you may want to bind the keys to your liking). Since there's less of them- we'll start with the bad things, shall we?Stealth games NEED good, balanced cpu opponents. While the game gets the awareness of guards correct on a standard basis- the dudes you're sneaking past can be remarkably stupid, and occasionally even the converse of that, as it has its faults sometimes with twitchy/schizophrenic AI.The character models' faces can be REALLY ugly. Mainly, that comes from stretching in an exaggerated expression, as grabbing someone and holding a knife to their neck raises their eyebrows roughly 3 feet above their face, and their mouths even wider than the area aforementioned. Their eyelids are also triangles.Another fault for the PC version is that it doesn't quite have the sound design that the xbox version did- sound effects don't fade and echo like they should. Which is kind of bizarre! It's not often that the console counterpart ends up sounding better than PC master race's version.There are a few issues in the multiplayer modes:Co-op-Game can desync and completely ♥♥♥♥ up a mission that you and your partner had spent an hour on-Framerate is LOCKED TO 30 FRAMES FOR SYNCHRONIZATION PURPOSES-This game absolutely hates when you Alt+Tab and will kick you off the server for doing it too muchVersus-Opens separate program-Completely different (and less visually appealing) engine-Resolutions only offered in 4:3 format (but can be easily fixed by editing default.ini)-Some of the maps are so huge it boggles your ♥♥♥♥ing mind that ubi thought only 4 players could support itNow then- I've told you what isn't so hot about the game, and if all of that turns you off, that's okay. So what makes Chaos Theory so great?Make no mistake, gameplay is the breading AND the frosting on this delicious cake. The engine is completely revamped from its' predecessors, which is a magical thing that they were able to tear down what they had before that was already superb, and make something that is nearly perfect. There's a new sound meter, that lets you take a look at just how noisy you are in a situation, which makes for a better sense of immersion- rather than LOUD/NOT LOUD. The new engine the game runs on feels substantially smoother than SC or Pandora Tomorrow (which is still yet to see a steam release); All of your actions, as well as the AI's, both look and feel realistic. There's no half-hearted spring step like the original, nor do guards have to hug walls to get past eachother. All you have to worry about is coming up with the method to either stun your foe, eliminate him, or how to slip past him unnoticed. I often prefer the latter, but when in co-op, you can't really trust your partner, nor yourself to be this stealthy. You're better off quick-saving frequently or just knocking out whomever you encounter (or both!).Sound-wise, the game sounds awesome. Stellar voice acting, great sound effects, and some of the greatest music in a game ever. In fact, Ubisoft was so pleased by composer Amon Tobin's work, they released the soundtrack a MONTH before the game was due. Tobin was able to create the tense atmosphere of the game, all while retaining the feel that you're a ghost's shadow. You ARE what goes bump in the night. Needless to say, the game's OST has wound up on every different generation of an MP3 player I've had.Seriously. Just listen to it. 


YouTube™ Video: 05 El Cargo 

			Views: 168,995		

			El Cargo by Amon Tobin from the Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory Original Soundtrack I Do Not Own Splinter Cell		

The voices in the game sound smooth and believable at every time. There's no forced lines like there were in Pandora Tomorrow, where there was that occasional young voice in the ambient audio tracks that absolutely did not fit the bill for the lines or the character he was given."DON'T SHOOT, I'M AMERICAN"That line is going to haunt me til the day I die.Like I've explained before, the game still looks nice, visually. The environments look polished, with the lights shining in just the right spots that make the game still a pleasure to look at, nearly a decade after release. The character models are very nicely detailed in terms of both texture, and shape. With bumps and edges on not just their faces, but clothing as well. In a game about stealth, you could imagine how important shadows and lighting are- and the balancing of the light-index along with the visuals work great (although this excludes a few particular downloadable co-op levels). The Co-op looks just like the Singleplayer, and doesn't sacrifice the engine for the sake of performance. But the extra levels included in the v1.05 patch leave a LOT to be desired. It feels like there was a completely different designer who had absolutely no spatial awareness, and didn't even understand how lighting works- and that large, stretched blood textures serve no purpose when there is no body they are connected to. Stay away from those maps if you wish not for your partner and yourself to succumb to occular leprosy. How do I love thee, Versus? Let me count the ways.1. When I grabbed parker and threw him off a ledge, breaking his neck.2. Charging into and scaring the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Binary_2 right after the elevator doors opened on 'Club House'.3. Both Parker and I getting killed after bd648 fired a grenade into the rafters, taking the ceiling along with it.4. wwchicken running headlong into yet another proximity mine next to the VIDEO GAMES terminal in 'River Mall'.Versus makes its' return from Pandora Tomorrow, and with a vengeance. Gameplay is considerably more balanced, providing an easier challenge for the mercs. Mercs can now hit spies in the FACE, and knock them down- which levels the playing field, since spies have a tendency to sneak up and break your neck. You can also customize your loadouts for both classes, which is nice when you're trying to balance the game to fit your playstyle. Spies are still stuck with their shocker rifle, but mercs have the option to take either their default assault rifle, an SMG, or a shotgun. There's various things you can use on both sides as well, including spy traps, tracking bullets, and even stealth camouflage. It's all there, and it's a blast to play. I have no idea why there's so few people playing such a fantastic game. I mean, Counterstrike came out 13 years ago, and it's still one of the most played games on Steam.Where is the JUSTICE.TL;DR This game is fun as hell. If you haven't played it, and you love to be a stealthy SOB, get your hands on this delicious classic. Don't care about the multiplayer/ have no friends? The singleplayer tells a great story that can be beaten anywhere from 10-20 hours. A great deal that you can get on steam for an average 5-10 bucks. Wouldn't miss it for the world.-BP

												Tom Clancy's: Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory: Featuring Tom Clancy is pretty cool, I guess. You play as Sam Fisher, the world's sneakiest dad. Sam works for an organization called Third Echelon, who's entire purpose is to spook the enemies of America and take their things. Over the course of a few missions, Sam discovers a conspiracy to do bad things to somebody or something and has to use all of his sneaky tricks to stop it. To be fair, I really like this game. Like, REALLY like this game. If I were to have to give a gold star to any game, it would probably be this one. Hurray, you did it! Mr. Clancy!Oh no, Mr. Clancy is dead! Bom Stancy's Stink Cell is one of those stealth games that actually focuses on stealth. Although you can go in loud and make a big scene, you are treated like a stinky idiot and penalized for it. In old games, if you got caught three times, the mission would end. The alarms are still there, but the missions don't end anymore, instead the enemies just get progressively more resistant to your presence. One alarm goes off and they know something is wrong, two alarms go off and they know something is definitely wrong and start packing heat, and on the third alarm they actually come looking for you. It's a pleasant difficulty spike that actually punishes you and spanks your bottom for playing like a Sally. Luckily, the stealth part of the game is the best part. You have two meters, the spook meter, and the loud noises meter. Stealth is based on line of sight and darkness, the darker it is, the harder you are to see, the spook meter actually shows how concealed you are in the dark, with the darkest meaning you can basically brush a guards beard sensually and whisper sweet nothings into his ear and he won't notice you, while if the meter is all the way to the light side you may as well be buying travel insurance and live in palm beach. Sound is also a big thing that can either aid or hinder your success. There is a cap that moves depending on how noisy your environments are. Like a thunderstorm or a loud engine can conceal the noise you make while a room with someone sleeping or a hollow cave will make you easier to hear. Your adversaries are usually guards, which is expected. The guards react to sound and when they think they saw something, but usually just bumble around until they realize something is amiss. What is pleasantly surprising is how the guards actually interact with one another. Outside of scripted conversations, they also coordinate with one another when they're looking around for something strange. While they're working together they usually have some kind of worried conversation about hoping not to find anything as well as mumbling to themselves if there's nobody looking with them. It really gives life to the guards in a genre that is usually void of any kind of personality for your opponents. You have a few ways of dispatching your foes. Outside of 007 style gadgets like the sticky camera and the shock shooty, you can also choose to either knock them out, whack em, or just bypass them all together. There really isn't a better feeling than getting into a area and out without anyone even knowing you were there to begin with. I am not going to continue to gush about this game.Back in the day, there was a big scene for Chaos Theory's multiplayer, and rightly so. There were two multiplayer modes, one where you yelled at your friend for alerting the guards in co-op mode. And one where you yelled at other people because they somehow saw you while you were across the hall in the dark behind a box in the competitive mode. Co-op mode was actually it's own game, where you and a friend took control of two freshly trained Splinter Cells as they went on missions that sometimes went on at the same time as Sam's outings. Each mission was built with team work in mind since the two agents had a set of moves they could perform like boosting each other on to high ledges, roping your partner down a deep pit, disrupting cameras with your microwave emitter while the other sneaks through the dark, and thinking about monster trucks and manly things while you climb your partner like a ladder and sensually rub against him. While Co-op was really cool, competitive was a beast all on it's own. The game was a two on two affair where a duo of spies part of an organization known as SHADOWNET infiltrated into facilities protected by a mercenary group known as ARGUS. When you play as Shadownet you play like a usual Splinter Cell with some extra moves and gadgets added in. But when you play as ARGUS, you play from a first person perspective and mostly rely on brute force and fire power. ARGUS patrols the map and guards the objectives while Shadownet has to sneak past them and steal the goodies without being spotted. Competitive is tense, like, poop in pants tense. You have very little offensive options as Shadownet and are forced to either run or get filled with new breathing holes when you get caught while ARGUS has no idea if a Shadownet agent is near unless he has his flashlight pointed directly at him, or his noise detector goes off. It's hide and seek but with more fire power. Both sides have enough options and gadgets to dispatch one another, like how Shadownet can break the necks of the ARGUS mercenaries they can sneak up on and how ARGUS can set up tripwires and mines to catch Shadownet spies off guard. It's an amazing mode and sadly has whittled over the years due to just how old the game is. But should you play Tem Sensy's Sneaky Guy: Math stuff? Its still one of my favorite games ever. Even though the multiplayer glory days are over, the single player is still top notch stuff. You can get your money's worth on single player alone, but if you can get a few friends together to spook one another, I would recommend that as well. I don't actually have a gold sticker, so I'm just going to thumb up the Xbox copy I have.Good on you, Xbox version of the game I reviewed.The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

												"Yeah, (I am) the real kind (of spy), not the tuxedo kind. I'm the kind that makes you bleed all over your Andretti unless you give me information." Chaos Theory is a third-person stealth video game and the third installment in Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell series. It, again, puts you in the boots of NSA (and Third Echelon) special agent Sam Fisher as he undertakes missions around the world to avert the possibility of an all-out war between military superpowers.The single-player campaign is divided into ten missions with locations ranging from the America's to East Asia. The game was released almost ten years back but it definitely holds well from a visual point of view. Missions usually take place at night (or in the dark) which probably help mask a few of the game's graphical deficiencies. Chaos Theory has probably some of the best stealth mechanics in any game. A sliding light bar indicates whether Sam would be visible to the enemy or not while a noise bar shows how much noise is being produced as the protagonist moves around. Sam's pace of movement is tunable by scrolling the mouse-wheel, giving players a much greater control over how the character moves. Enemies can be sneaked upon from behind and knocked-out or put in the choke-hold to extract vital information. Apart from moving around in the shadows, the game provides you the option of traversing through vents, zip-lines, hang from ledges and overhead pipes; all the while avoiding enemy encounters.The game is designed around stealth so players would experience gun fights to be clunky in nature. Apart from the usual arsenal of silenced pistol, sticky cameras. stun grenades and assault rifles, there's a very useful EMI feature that allows you to remotely disable lights and electronics temporarily. It helps a lot in moving around the environment unscathed. Hacking is a fundamental portion of the game. Computers, keypads and security terminals can be hacked, with the mechanic favouring those with quick reaction times. Multi-vision goggles are once again an essential part of gameplay with Sam able to alternate between night-vision, thermal and EMF modes.The enemy AI is excellent with sentries coming to snoop around if they see open doors or turned-off lights. Enemies can also be distracted by whistling and flinging objects around the environment. Instances of direct combat are extremely rare but if such a scenario does crop up, enemies take cover and periodically change positions to improve their chances of winning gunfights. The plot was interesting but not something that hasn't be done already or since. The script is well-written and character voice-overs are extremely well done (Michael Ironside ftw!). But I felt character interactions felt a bit too formal and serious. Mission briefs involve relevant characters droning off about mission objectives, although there's some fun banter between Sam and his handlers during missions; but that's few and far between. The game could've done with more cutscenes, in my opinion.Chaos Theory is a definite recommendation if you're looking for a pure stealth experience. The SP campaign length is around 12-15 hours, subject to one's playing style of course. The game is definitely much much better than the p.o.s that was Splinter Cell: Conviction.

It still looks good today, the mechanics are still top notch and mostly, it has tons of features you'd expect from a modern game, without all the flaws you can guess.I don't know if it's just me, but stealth in FPS view always felt awkward and unpractical to me. Granted, it's mostly close-quarters.Storywise, it's nothing revolutionnary but it fits well. You follow a linear line up to the bad guys and get em down one by one up until the end. Politicals, bureaucrats, bankers... they all wanted a piece of that cake.The OST ranges from forgettable to annoying, especially when you do a quick takedown and have to stand a minute or so of "ACTION MUSIC" for no reason. Perfect stealth gameChaos theory is the best splinter cell game and arguably one of the best stealth games ever created.The story is somewhat realistic and interesting. Tensions are running high as North Korea is threatening an all out war against America and her allies. You play as Sam Fisher, an ex-SEAL member now a 'cell' (spy) working for the a top secret sub-branch within the National Security Agency (NSA). It's your job to uncover who is behind jeopardising the relationship between the two countries and risking all out war.The gameplay is the best component of the game. Before each mission you get a briefing with other members of Third Eschalon and their allies telling you the task and situation of the mission. You then get to select your loadout based on 'Stealth' (more stealth equipment like smoke grenades and sticky cameras), 'Assault' (More assault rifle ammo and frag grenades) or 'Reddington' (Mixture of the other two) which affects the types of equipment you will have and how much of each item you carry with you. The three options of equipment speak for themselves on how you want to approach the mission. The equipment you may have include the sileneced assault rifle, silenced pistol, sticky cameras, smoke grenades, stun grenades, frags etc. The objectives in each mission will generally require you to steal, sabotage or eliminate a target. As a 'splinter cell game' stealth gameplay is highly recommended. Besides hiding in the shadows, a new element plays a role in in the gameplay, noise. Creating too much noise (more than the ambient sound in the area which is indicated by a bar on your hud) will now cause foes to detect you which may include gun noises, broken glass and movement. As such, you can control your walking speed (which increases noise as it increases) via the scrolling the mouse wheel. The final element to the gameply is manipulating electronics via your pistol. By aiming your pistol and pressing right mouse button you can turn off an electronic device for a few seconds. The purpose of this is to not destroy the item and hence, alerting the gaurds. You can go all guns blazing in most of the missions, but this is not recommended as it not only ruins the atmosphere of the game, but you  die very quickly in frontal combat. As per usual you can eliminate gaurd using lethal force or non-lethal force. Shooting gaurds is lethal as well as choosing the lethal option when grabing them from behind. Non-lethal involves choosing non-lethal ammo and knocking gaurds out after grabbing them. Another new element to the gampley is the ability to quickly walk up to gaurds and knock them out/kill them, which helps when your about to be spotted at close range.The level design is excellent. Each level is big and unique, spotting plenty of places places to hide in such as shadows. Furthermore, there are more than one route to reach objectives including vents, doors, tunnels etc. The graphics has also aged well and looks pleasant. Finally the levels are so well designed that you can go through the entire game without killing/knocking out anyone and not being detected either.The audio is good. Voice actors (especially Sam) do a great job at instilling the emotions of the current situation. Weapon sound are also good as well. Each level has a unique track that is played while stealthed and while being spotted. Each level has a unique soundtrack for the the previous two situations, so you won't get bored from hearing the same tarck over and over again.If you want one of the best stealth games ever made, chaos theory will not dissapoint you.

												This is considered my favorite game of all time, and to make sure I have your attention now I'll tell you why :-Awesome storyline-Chaos theory has the best multiplayer of any splinter cell -There are co-op missions that me and my cousin spent countless hours on (unfortunately the PC port doesn't have it... for some dumb reason). -The gameplay is amazing as there is never one way to get through a scenario-The graphics are still relevant to today's high tech worldNow the detailed explanation.The storyline is epic. Why is it epic? Splinter cell series has always been known to have a crazy or sort of conspiracy storyline, chaos theory delivers a lot more than that. Two lead programmers that cracked Philippe Masse's kernals from the first splinter cell have enhanced his algorithms and now could be used for any electronic warfare, be it military or economic. One of these programmers is discovered dead early in the game, and the other one on the loose... the story just begins to exponentially get better from there.The multiplayer was my favorite in this game as it gave me everything I wanted. I want to play online ... okay go ahead. I want to play with my friend on the same screen or at my house and he at his... fine go ahead. Want to play competitively as a spy? Fine. Want to play as a guard and take down spies with a first person view.... heck the devs cared so much they did this too. When someone really gives an effort to really allow any sort of play when it comes to multiplayer, it's greatly appreciated. I would say the gameplay of this game is arguably the best type out there. The physics/engine in this one is what would one expect from a third game of the series. I would argue that still to this day even though there are other Splinter Cell's out there, this one still has the best game engine. The soft body touches, the noise system, throwing of objects to make noise, ability to whistle, use the SC-20K it's sniping/assault attachment or it's launcher attachments, the grenade types (frag, flash, smoke), the three different goggle settings (heat, night vision, ECM), ability to either knock out or kill an opponent... there's quite a bit of things to mention. I like the fact you are given a choice of going through vents or alternate ways to avoid conflict or can go through conflict, or one by one slowly "put to sleep and hide the bodies" conflict. The greatest improvement though compared to the first splinter cell is that there is flexibility in the proximity system. When one is close to the enemy, they don't ultimately see/feel you just because they walked past you going through a doorway. This game is fantastic in how you are able to knock someone out or kill someone before they can react. This was a major breakthrough in the series.How are the graphics still good for an original x-box game? Well how's 1980X1080 sound? Probably the best we can get unless someone goes through the entire game and re-does it... but there wouldn't be much to redo. The cut scenes are still awesome, and the game play graphics are just as good as any game. You will not have an issue with graphics playing this. Sounds? Listen carefully to hear Sam make remarks as he moves about or the guards talking about some random topic. I'm not being biased in my rating as it being my favorite game, but this game is what took the gaming industry to another level. Product received for free
 Does it have a premise? You're Sam Fisher, at this point, veteran Third Echelon covert operative. Tensions are rising in Asia, mainly between Japan and North Korea. Do your job, sneak and defuse this situation. You're not going to earn a medal. Nobody knows what you did except for you and your handlers. How does it play? This is  one of the very best stealth games to ever exist , only second to the two original Thief series. The sound you make is properly emulated, accounted for and displayed. There are no obviously broken light levels, unlike the original Splinter Cell. It provides you with difficulty options that are tailored for the average stealth player, the type of person who knows the game by heart and the masochist. You have several ways of approaching each level. Maps are built like actual places, with several, unplanned ways in and out that you can utilize. You also have a choice between lethal and non-lethal, though killing people does take away from your overall score. Does it have music?  Why, yes. It's by far  the best soundtrack in a Splinter Cell title , each and every track is memorable and just fantastic. Does it have co-op? This game has great co-op, transporting the original solo experience to co-op almost perfectly. The only problem is that it is way too short. Given more levels, this would be a perfect co-op mode for one of the finest stealth games.Oh and also, servers are down, so you'll have to use a third-party service that emulates LAN servers. Does it have multiplayer? ...it's bad. It is far more about rushing out and killing your opponent than actual stealth. Also, you can't play it without the hassle of setting up. If you haven't played this and have no nostalgia for it, don't even bother. Who should play this? It's a must-play for any stealth game enthusiast. It's also a must-play for anyone who wants to get into stealth games. It's a must play for anyone who hasn't played it, for it is one of the video games that I would honestly call a master work. It has only one notable blemish, and it's more of a side addition you have the choice to skip completely.

												It is amazing how a 12 year old game can hold up for this long.For many including myself. Chaos Theory has been the defining chapter in this franchise. The one that all other chapters are compaired to. For me, Chaos Theory improved upon the concept from the first two titles and made a defining atmosphere in which we the player actually feel like a super spy when we play. Much like Theif and Metal Gear and how those franchises defined the genre, Chaos Theory added new elements that would help define future stealth gameplay.I think the reason why so many hold this title to be the best Splinter Cell is because it was followed by Double Agent which forked off into a more casual style of stealth. Which continued further up the line with Conviction. Blacklist, while still holding the causal aspect introduced with Double Agent. Did try to re-focus on the core of the franchise and what made it great.I remeber getting the demo disk in an issue of Xbox Magazine which consisted of the Lighthouse mission. I was so captivated by it that by the time the game actually released. I had played that mission hundreds of times. What really made this game for me though was the introduction of co-op. Something that I had always wanted to do in Splinter Cell. I enjoyed Chaos Theory so much that it was a staple in LAN parties with my group for several years.I bought this on Steam a few years ago and never got around to playing it. Having just recently garnered an interest in going back and playing all the old titles, I remembered that I had this in my library. While the game itself is 12 years old, I do like how it looks on PC. It's no Witcher 3, but for a 2005 title. It looks damn good in my opinion.Controls took some getting used to for me. I was so used to playing this game on a controller that it felt alien for me to play on mouse & keyboard. But I quickly got comfortable after 30 or so minutes. The story is the only thing that I feel to be dated. It's no masterpeice but it gets the job done in getting you hooked. Then again, the story wasn't really Chaos Theory's main driving point either in what made it popular.So far I have been enjoying it. That rush of nostalgia that I get with every favorable spot and event puts a smile on my face. The gameplay is something that I wish the following titles kept. I hope the next instalment goes back to the franchise's roots and brings back the Splinter Cell we all know and love.I highly recommend this game for anyone looking to get a feel on what Splinter Cell has been about. What once was a defining title in the stealth genre. It still looks, sounds, plays, and feels like a fun and enjoyable game even after all these years. It also has a good degree of difficulty if you want to achieve 100% Ghost statistics on the missions. So it will offer a nice challenge too if that's what you're looking for.You are also still able to play the co-op and Spy vs Merc MP by using Hamachi or Tunggle. So that's a plus as well.

												This has always been and will always be my personal favorite in the Splinter Cell series. The stealth gameplay here is phenomenal, challenging, and has a greater sense of believability than later entries. If you have played Conviction and/or Blacklist, be warned: those games are much faster paced than Chaos Theory. Chaos Theory requires a great deal more patience and the action is less flashy, but you feel like a genuine badass picking off enemies from the shadows. This is only accented by the game's difficulty level; it is a challenging game, especially on harder difficulties, but I never found it to be unfair.The level design is very well done here across the board (single player, co-op, and versus modes all taken into consideration) and offer a variety of paths to complete your mission. There is also plenty of variety in the settings for these levels, from lighthouses to cruise ships to banks. The graphics for this game were phenomenal for the time and still hold up surprisingly well (particularly shadows and lighting effects), although character models can tend to look very "blah" compared to today's standards. The audio is honestly one of my favorite parts of the game. The music is great and fits the in-game tension perfectly, the voice actors  did a great job and have some funny dialogue, and Michael Ironside will ALWAYS be the true voice of Sam Fisher. Good lord, that voice.The multiplayer in this game is phenomenal too. The versus mode is a fun "Spies vs. Mercenaries" mode where spies, who sneak around in third-person, attempt to hack information from terminals while the more lethally equipped mercenaries (who are controlled like a first-person shooter) attempt to stop them. It's an entertaining game of cat and mouse. The co-op mode also has it's own completely separate campaign from the single player version; however, it upholds the same standards of level design, challenge, and fun. I'm a big fan of co-op games and this is among the very best, in my opinion.**An important note on the multiplayer: The Ubisoft servers for this game are down and you will be unable to play if you attempt to log in directly online through the game. There is a VERY easy workaround for this, however. I am currently using software called Evolve that allows you to create a virtual LAN connection with other friends, which allows you to play this game online through the LAN menu. I am mentioning this  because it's free and I truly think it is worth the time.**Honestly, there's a lot to love here. Over the years this quickly became one of my all-time favorite games and still is to this day. If you are a fan of stealth games or you're simply looking for a challenge, I am certain you will adore this game.

First Impressions/Thoughtstldr; Splinter Cell Chaos Theory is not a perfect game - but as old as it is, you can find it surprisingly fun to play and fairly easy to get into.The Gameplay - Fundamental ChangesChaos Theory on is focused mainly on sneaking and getting from point A to D. You will occasionally be lockpicking doors, hacking, hiding bodies, interrogating enemies, etc. Killing isn't a necessity to progress, either. Feel free to speedrun through (most) levels as a pacifist!Graphical Fidelity - DirectX Support, Overall QualityThere are several video options regarding quality. It supports HDR, Shader Model 3.0, Anisotrophic Filtering, Anti-Aliasing, and such. This includes widescreen-monitor support as well. Unfortunately, Versus Mode is completely different - locked at 30 frames, only supports DirectX 8, no 16:9/16:10 ratio support, various missing or unincluded game options, and overall a huge disadvantage. It is most similiar to Pandora Tomorrow in terms of quality and gameplay elements.The Community - Servers, GamespyMy only problem with the game that remains is the lack of players. The modding community on the other hand is still fairly active. In another note, Gamespy servers have been long since shut down, and much of the fanbase has moved on, especially after Splinter Cell: Blacklist was released in 2013. You will likely notice less than 15 players a day in Versus lobbies, and an even smaller number of players in CO-OP lobbies. I recommend bringing some friends along to ease the stress of waiting and finding more games to join.Final Rating - What It DeservesThe game deserves my overall 9/10 rating. I've never given a game such a high rating, and my expectations have always been rather high for most games. It's worth it. Bear in mind that it isn't perfect, and it still has it's fair share of issues to this day. But it is *the* perfect stealth game.

												Remains one of the best stealth games ever made, and still one of the best games of all time really. Easily the best in the Splinter Cell series, this is in my top 5 favorite games ever. Every element this game aims for, it achieves perfectly. The graphics are amazing for the time, the gameplay is fantastic and requires patience and skill, and the map design actually allows some exploration but keeps things focused. It's pretty laughable at times when it drops dates "this is 2008... the future!" but as a game it works unbelievably well. It's the most balanced when it comes to combat vs stealth, in that it's very realistic in how it handles it. If someone catches you off guard, they can kill you pretty much instantly, but the same goes for all the enemies.Playing the newer installments, it's sad how simple they've become. It's not a simple "it's new so it sucks thing", this one is better than the older installments. It has just the right balance of skill requirement vs being accessible and holds up the best. You have to manage how well you're lit up or how loud you are compared to the environment masking your footsteps, but it's easy to do and incredibly rewarding once you master it. Some games like the Hitman series or the newer Splinter Cell installments don't really do the stealth elements well enough to really get into it, but this game achieves it perfectly. You do need to stay hidden but it's fun and worth it to get that badass feeling of coming out of the shadows with your knife, or whistling to get a guards attention and snap his neck from a pipe above as he nears you. Co-op missions are decent if you have a friend to play it with, but the story mode is the main focus as it should be. The soundtrack, dark visuals, and excellent stealth gameplay are just amazing. If you're into stealth games especially, I recommend this. It isn't an action shooter.

												Probably the best Splinter Cell game in the series. The gameplay and controls work so well on the PC, which is surprising considering the fact that Ubisoft is notorious about porting to PC. The story is like your typical Splinter Cell game where there is this super bad guy trying to hurt America and so you, Sam Fisher, have to save the world once again. This time there is a plot twist but I won't spoil it. In this game, there is now more interrogations than having to read boring data sticks from previous games. Some of them are actually pretty funny. Back in the day, there were more game modes available that include co-op and Versus mode but it's pretty much irrelevant at this point as I can no longer get a game going. For the price today I suggest you pick up this game as it's stealth at the finest level polish. To my surprise, half of the effects this game uses is not even present in double agent. 												Chaos Theory is the proverbial second Spliner Cell game, and it shows. Like a lot of series, the second game is often the best. It perfected the system of the first, and it hasn't gone downhill yet. Kinda like Assassin's Creed 2 is still considered one of the best, if not the best. Games in that aspect, tends to follow the same rules as movies.Sure there was Pandora Tomorrow in between, but no one wants to remember Pandora Tomorrow... It could as well not exist seeing it's not in the bundle and it's apparently unplayable due to shadow issues.Thoses considerations aside, Chaos Theory pretty much improved on all aspects. Graphisms are nice, still good nowdays without being stellar, animations are fluid, Fisher got new moves, the HUD give more indications on the noise you emit and the lighting, missions are more intresting and involved, people you grab can be interrogated for some pretty hilarious, or sometimes meaningful dialogues, and controls are a lot more PC friendly.Scenario isn't really that much better than the first game, Fisher is going to save the US/Free World again, against a group of mooks no one really cares about and which are easyly forgetable.The game is more about its gameplay, which is pretty good at what it does, without being the miracle people would like it to be. You will probably enjoy your time playing it, bar some minor annoyances such as scripted events you have limited to no control on, then put the game on a shelf.A good purchase to get during a sale, at least, and a classic.

												One of the best stealth games.Certainly a classic, and the strongest entry in the Splinter Cell series imho.Also runs on a potato.Which is what I used when I first played it on release, ya know, back in the day with those high falutin cd rom devices.You can tackle most of the missions all guns blazing if you want, or opt for the classier stealth method - but with all the different weapons, tools, distractions, and environmental opportunities available to you both paths are generally viable.When using stealth, you will find that patience, observation of the enemy and exploration are rewarded. Taking the time to learn patrol routes, and finding convenient ways to dispose of corpses or making a mental note of sneaky exits for when the mission goes wrong all go a long way here.Fortunately the levels are very well designed and encourage this whilst still giving you other options.The soundtrack is generally awesome, being composed by the legendary composer Jesper Kyd and the ambience of all the environments really helps to draw you in.And the lighting. While the graphics still hold up well today, this was one of the first games that allowed destruction of lights.Yes it is possible to shoot them out entirely - strangely satisfying with a "pffft" from the silenced pistol.That being said the accurate yet cool default pistol is also posessed of a better function that temporarily disables them (and cctv cameras) - it can shoot emp waves at short range.How cool is that?Its an even quieter method than the silenced pistol, does not waste ammo, and draws less attention if people decide to investigate. The light, or camera in question will soon reactivate and be perceived as a power fluctuation or some glitch which doesnt bother guards apparently. Just long enough for you to sneak past though or silently slit someones throat...

The game is mission-based and although each mission has several objectives, only the primary ones are needed to complete the mission.  How you complete your mission is very open-ended and there are often multiple paths and ways of doing things.  You can be as ruthless as you want, deciding whether or not to kill people (or simply avoid them entirely).Despite having been released in 2005, the game still looks impressive.  The controls are complex and some people might have a learning curve to get over, but please stick with it. Unlike lots of more recent games, Chaos Theory allows you to not only save (both manual and quick saves) whenever and wherever you want, but name them as well.All in all, I suggest playing it if you like stealth games.  If not, don't bother.

												As a guy who's played Conviction first, I have to say I'm actually having more fun playing this game more. While I still feel like the controls could've been better, something I also feel about Double Agent, I enjoy the game immensely. The most obvious reason for the game is the story, which isn't "US vs. Russia". From what I can gather, it's North Korea.Chaos Theory is also easily the best game in the series, according to the dozens of reviews by new fans and Splinter Cell veterans alike. I certainly would agree; stealth is paramount in any situation. Sam's suit comes with a variety of items to help you know when you're hidden, or when you've screwed the pooch. Light sensors to let you know when you're visible, sound detectors to let you know how slow you need to move to keep quiet. An option I'm familiar with because of Double Agent is the OPSAT, which is a real-time objectives and map menu, meaning you'll need to hide to use it effectively. Hacking is way more interesting than Double Agent, and shooting, when done right, feels like an accomplishment.Graphics wise, character models in game show visible age and are acceptable if you remember it's from 2005. Environments though show great lighting and attention to detail. I did get a feeling of being in the locations Sam visited. And again, for a game in 2005, it looks just as good as some games from this decade.Sound is phenomanal, with a soundtrack by Amon Tobin and layered for different events in gameplay so it never feels stale. Sam Fisher is voiced by Michael Ironside; not the new guy who everyone hates for some ridiculous reason. Seriously guys, move on. In fact the voice acting and the script writing are good too; minus the enemy/foreign character voices. While Sam and his pals are witty and relatable, enemies tend to have such bad and stereotyped accents. And let's not forget the character "Long Dan". Turning on native voices solves this, but there's no subtitle option to let you know what's being said, so it's more for immersion after beating the game.So yes, I'm joining the bandwagon. But at least it's a good one; Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is easily one of the best stealth games I've played. And it's one that really deserves it.

												Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is an amazing game and instantly worth a recommend if you are a fan of the stealth genre or just like the series and haven't gotten into the 3rd instalment for some reason. It's worthy of its Steam-tag "Best in the series". I have debated with myself about it, but I would add this game to one of my favourite games of all-time. No, I am not a huge stealth enthusiast. Also being a legacy title, it doesn't have any UPlay integration at all!A good stealth game is dependant on solid mechanics and unlike later instalments of Splinter Cell. Chaos Theory and its predecessors are mostly stealth driven games.  Sam Fisher is given 3 settings in his trademark 3-scope goggles (Night-Vision, Heat-Vision and an EEV mode which highlights electronic equipment),  an EMP function on his handgun and of course a knife.  The game also features  sound and light bars in the HUD to show how silent and hidden you are which is a nice touch. With these tools, some environmental manipulation and the solid controls it's possible to get through entire missions without being detected or firing a bullet. Infact in the 1st mission I got through with only firing 2 on normal difficulty.Controls are excellent here on the PC with a keyboard & mouse. With the controls already premapped sensibly and are all rebindable.  A notable control mechanic is how you can alter Fisher's walking/sneaking speed via the scroll wheel of the mouse which is a really nice touch. The game does have a good tutorial which teaches you how to work with these efficiently.The plot is worthy of the Tom Clancy name and is immensely detailed. I didn't understand it as a child in 2005 and I still only have a relative understanding of it now with some help from the Wiki and knowledge from previous playthroughs. It follows on from the previous 2 installments and takes you all around the world. That's the idea of the plot without mentioning spoilers.Visuals are from the Unreal Engine 2.5 and are pretty solid. The game is from 2005, so it's safe to say that the visuals are antiquated. The lighting plays a key role in the game as it can be the difference between having bullets hurled at Fisher. The textures are antiquated for the most part, but that's to be expected. Still it doesn't look too bad for a 2005 game.Soundtrack was composed by both Amon Tobin and the well-know Jesper Kyd. The OST is amazing and each tune has a unique vibe that sets the scene whether it be ambient whilst Sam Fisher is sneaking around or frantic when enemies are firing at you due to your carelessness. It was also apparently featured on the UK motoring TV show Top Gear which says quite a bit and my favourite tracks from El Cargo (the 2nd mission) have been part of my personal music library for quite some time.So all in all give it a try. At its current price of £9.99 ($9.99/9.99€), it's not a bad deal for stealth enthusasts. Though it has been reduced by Ubisoft to at least 75% making it cost around £2.50, I would it's worth getting for most gamers.That's all I can say about the game. You decide if you want to sneak, when to distract, what tools to use, from which direction to leap upon guards etc. I feel it's hard to put into words how the game manages to pull off beautifully many things, aiming for Sam to be a stealthy ninja, a predator, a covert operative with many tricks, moves and gadgets up his sleeve, which add up to a fun balance of power, not making the player feel too powerful (the difficulty isn't hard for this game, which isn't too offputting) but not too weak. AI has a variety of tricks, though it isn't anything mindblowing, it is still enough to remind the player that you better anticipate some pushback from the npcs.I think the campaign was short, I haven't played it through yet (again), but the length and replayability is still decent.Graphics are still highly enjoyable for an older game and has solid frames per second with highest settings. A proper mix of dynamic shadows, decent shaders and textures, solid animations and physics, allowed me to still immerse myself into the game without being distracted by too much unrealism. Doesn't mean you should expect the quality of modern games, but this game does enough, in my opinion, to still be eyecandy, the basic solid kind of candy, like milk chocolate.Happily reinstalling this game on my mediocre laptop, I didn't find many problems, which I were slightly expecting, due to so many, not merely old games, but newer ones also having so many problems (which can nevertheless be fixed in many cases). The major problem is that shader model 3 doesn't work for me, the screen goes white, but upon investigation I think it has more to do with the intel HD graphics card than the game, or my drivers anyway (SM2 is still good and looks good). My laptop is a win7, intel dual core 2gHz, 4gRAM with shared graphics card memory, dedicated only 64mb. So it might just work for the majority. I should add that I always add the admin rights and compatibility mode XPSP3 by habit, so that might also have had something to do with it.People who are not even fans of stealth games might find SCCT a luring gateway drug into the world of patient stalking and picking your own time when to pick npcs off one by one with satisfaction.

												One of the greatest stealth games ever created. It's in the Holy Trinity of stealth games, along with Thief 2 and Hitman Blood Money.Gameplay: There's a light and dark stealth system, which means that staying in the dark is crucial to sneaking by. Some of the tensest moments are spent hiding in the dark while a guy with a huge gun is so close you can see his nosehairs. You can always see how visible you are and how much noise you are making in the HUD, which provides a lot of convienence. You can also use sounds in the enviorment to mask sounds you are making, like thunder. I recall one moment where you have to open a loud door in front of a sleeping guard, and if you don't open it while he's snoring, he'll wake up. You can also interrogate guards you've grabbed, and it leads to a lot of hilarious and memorable moments. The gadgets from Pandora Tomorrow make a return (the previous game in the series) while adding some new additions to Fisher's arsenal. The gameplay overall is tense and satisfying, and makes you feel like a badass spy.Graphics: The lighting system is brilliant, and looks better than most modern games. The character models, however, are lack luster. I remember one specific guard who's gums were light green. And Sam himself, when he's not wearing mask, has a consistent cross-eyed dumb look on his face. The textures are fine, not really anything special. It looks fine, overall.Sound: When the absolutely kickass music isn't playing, there's atmospheric sounds and really sets the mood. The sound design of effects like footsteps rivals even the Thief games. The enemies have very stereotypical accents, and it's done for laughs. The music starting to play when an enemy is suspicous and is looking for you really kicks up the tension.The sound design overall, is fantastic.Level Design: There's usually at least one alternate way to get into an area (although it heavily relies on pipes and crawl spaces.) It's non-linear and sprawling (excluding the first level) and is fun to explore. The level design is great (while not anywhere near the masterful level design of the Thief games.)Conclusion: Buy this game. If you're looking to get into stealth games, this is the game. One of the greatest games I've ever played.And I don't know why the enemies can't see the 3 suns on top of Fisher's head, shut up.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
The best Splinter Cell title ever madeSo, Blacklist turned out to be pretty good and a huge improvement over Conviction which was a detraction from the core SC formula. However, the definitive SC experience will always be Chaos Theory, which largely corrected the flaws of the previous games while further improving the strengths.When this game released in 2005, it was a graphical masterpiece that pushed the consoles to their limits, and also put strain on the most powerful PC GPUs of the time. Ten years later, the graphics still hold up pretty well, especially the lighting effects which are essential to the stealth gameplay. The freedom of choice you get in this game is incredible, and sadly absent in the later titles. In previous games, it was difficult to do things more than one way. That guard HAD to be KOed/killed. That door's lock HAD to be picked. There was rarely more than one path. In Chaos Theory, the levels are more sandbox-like, with multiple possible routes for you to discover. You can break locks or you can spend time picking them.. You can wait for a guard to come walking up to a door, and then slam it into his face with all your strength, or you can wait for him to turn away, and do a standard stealth KO. You can open a door slowly, pushing it a little more forward with each press of the W key, or you can fling it open and exposing yourself. You can hack electronic locks or retinal scanners or you can force guards to cooperate. You can hack PCs to disable lasers and cameras or you can play a dodging minigame. It's also much easier to carve your own 100% avoidance path this time because you get a lot of room to breathe.Every single enemy could be interrogated which expanded gameplay possibilities and also made for amusing easter eggs. The alarm system was much more forgiving without making the game too easy. Gone are the days of instant-failure because some dude saw you even if he didn't get a chance to radio for backup. The story was quite engaging, and made Sam Fisher more involved in the plot rather than just an everyday cleanup guy.AI was significantly improved from older games. Enemies would start using flashlights, lighting flares, and calling backup instead of just walking blindly towards the sight of a broken light.Melee attacks, a serious letdown in the past, are now my favourite way to deal with trouble. Sam Fisher now gets a knife that can do one-hit kills. If he wants to go non-lethal, he throws a fast punch to the head - a LOT more effective and realistic than the stupid elbow move in the previous games. Chaos Theory isn't a shooter, and it's difficult to play it like one without dying within seconds. Nevertheless, should the♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan, the guns are more effective than before, giving you choices of attachments (gadget launcher or shotgun or sniper attachment?) and making ammo more readily available (you can now carry more than 2 mags per gun at a time). The pistol is more accurate so you don't waste so many rounds to take out one light. 												Chaos Theory is the 3rd in the critically acclaimed Splinter Cell series which is based on Tom Clancy's series of novels with the similar name. This is an 8 year old game that actually aged quite well: some of the levels look quite good and the game utilises the lighting and shadow effects superbly.You play as Sam Fisher, member of a secret US black ops team, and are dispatched to various locations in order to find evidence, defuse a bomb, eliminate a terrorist, capture someone alive, etc. Although the game is linear, throughout the missions you are given secondary and opportunity objectives, therefore, the game tries to lengthen the singleplayer experience as much as possible. At the end of each level you are given a rating in accordance with the number of objectives you completed. In addition to this, the game counts whether or not you killed someone - this, in fact, lowers your score so it's best to focus on the stealth approach, otherwise achieving 100% is impossible. While making sure you are not seen by anybody or any cameras you can also knock your enemies out and hide the bodies.I like how varied the environment is: Sam can use a lot of objects, can climb a lot of things and can hang from a lot of places. There are also minigames in each level: you can do a lot of lockpicking, hacking and before knocking out or killing someone it's worth interrogating them to get some more intel for your objective. These interrogations can be funny due to the well-written script.It is unfortunate that coop and multiplayer are not played anymore, so, if this is on sale, make sure you grab it but only for the singleplayer experience.

The best Splinter Cell title ever madeSo, Blacklist turned out to be pretty good and a huge improvement over Conviction which was a detraction from the core SC formula. However, the definitive SC experience will always be Chaos Theory, which largely corrected the flaws of the previous games while further improving the strengths.When this game released in 2005, it was a graphical masterpiece that pushed the consoles to their limits, and also put strain on the most powerful PC GPUs of the time. Ten years later, the graphics still hold up pretty well, especially the lighting effects which are essential to the stealth gameplay. The freedom of choice you get in this game is incredible, and sadly absent in the later titles. In previous games, it was difficult to do things more than one way. That guard HAD to be KOed/killed. That door's lock HAD to be picked. There was rarely more than one path. In Chaos Theory, the levels are more sandbox-like, with multiple possible routes for you to discover. You can break locks or you can spend time picking them.. You can wait for a guard to come walking up to a door, and then slam it into his face with all your strength, or you can wait for him to turn away, and do a standard stealth KO. You can open a door slowly, pushing it a little more forward with each press of the W key, or you can fling it open and exposing yourself. You can hack electronic locks or retinal scanners or you can force guards to cooperate. You can hack PCs to disable lasers and cameras or you can play a dodging minigame. It's also much easier to carve your own 100% avoidance path this time because you get a lot of room to breathe.Every single enemy could be interrogated which expanded gameplay possibilities and also made for amusing easter eggs. The alarm system was much more forgiving without making the game too easy. Gone are the days of instant-failure because some dude saw you even if he didn't get a chance to radio for backup. The story was quite engaging, and made Sam Fisher more involved in the plot rather than just an everyday cleanup guy.AI was significantly improved from older games. Enemies would start using flashlights, lighting flares, and calling backup instead of just walking blindly towards the sight of a broken light.Melee attacks, a serious letdown in the past, are now my favourite way to deal with trouble. Sam Fisher now gets a knife that can do one-hit kills. If he wants to go non-lethal, he throws a fast punch to the head - a LOT more effective and realistic than the stupid elbow move in the previous games. Chaos Theory isn't a shooter, and it's difficult to play it like one without dying within seconds. Nevertheless, should the♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan, the guns are more effective than before, giving you choices of attachments (gadget launcher or shotgun or sniper attachment?) and making ammo more readily available (you can now carry more than 2 mags per gun at a time). The pistol is more accurate so you don't waste so many rounds to take out one light. The rifle with its attachments can make for many interesting possibilities (long range stealth kills, sticky shocker KOs, etc). Co-op mode was the first of its kind, allowing two players to play as Splinter Cells and boost each other over walls and work in tandem to do coordinated kills. It was even more fun than the campaign, but sadly a bit short.I've never tried Spies vs Mercenaries so no comment there.Anyone who enjoys stealth games like Metal Gear Solid and Hitman will find this well worth a few bucks.

												Again it's very late to write the review of this game - as it was release for quite a long back.Still, I am compelled to write the same cause of the game itself. As usual I will be dividing my review in parts. So without any further adieu lets jump into the business here - Story: The plot is, as with any other "Splinter Cell" title, is self-untangling. At the beginning player will have a very limited knowledge about the entire plot and that is revealed as the game is progressed. The plot itself may not appeal to the average FPS people, who are looking for Aim-n-Shoot kinda play through. But if you invest enough time and senses into the game - the plot is very apt and con-sized.Gameplay: The best part of any "Splinter Cell" title. Yes, though its not an open world environment, still there are more than 1 ways to complete most of the missions. The player will be given ample scope and time and equipments to complete each of the missions as the way they see fit. Players can vary their tactics - they can go complete "Stealth" and not raise a SINGLE!! alarm to complete mission or they can take a bit more direct approach to solve mattes - using bullets, that is.The tools are great and fun to use as well - be it a sticky camera or optical fiber or Lock Pic they can make the players life a lot less painful.Graphics: Now, when we talk about in game graphics - we usually bring out some of the big names of the business but very easily forget about "Splinter Cell" titles. Even for an old game like Chaos Theory, trust me, the graphics is great. The shadows and the ambient glow from the street/table/wall lamps are just too good. But the best part of all of them are the different vision mode of Sam Fisher's goggles. To me, the "Night Vision" is one of the best rendered "night mode" across all the game titles.AI: The AI is a strong point in this game - specially how they react to a whisper or when they see a body. Some of the guards are as ignorant as ever yet some of they are very suspicious (even of their own breathing). AI bots take some predefined paths or some random one - specially after they are being alerted. Even an open door or torn curtain can raise there suspicion. Be very careful to watch your light and ambient noise meter all the time - and don't hesitate to grab one if needed.All in all I am really enjoying the game and I would surely recommend anyone who is looking a different breed of the FPS genre.- Go Covert -

												So here is my review of "Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory".(just imagine and low voiced guy saying Tom Clancy)TL;DR it's in my top 10 stealth games, get it.So I'm going to split my review up into 4 sections, gameplay, story, graphics, & how does it compare to the newer games(?).GAMEPLAYTom Clancy's splinter cell CT has problems but also does things that I adore.Ok, stealth; the stealth in this game is realistic but it gets kinda annoying after a while.You see, there are 2 monitors attached to your U.I called your "aural monitor" and your "brightness monitor". Now of course your brightness has a big impact on you and your enemies. The bar works like a brightness setting I guess. Point is, the closer you get to light, the farther left (right?) it goes. If you are in full brightness then enemies I believe from anywhere can see you. Now the Aural monitor is the annoying part. The aural monitor watches your speed setting, the faster you go the easier enemies can hear you. Now the scoll wheel on your mouse functions as a speed changer, the closer you get to enemies the lower you scroll your mouse because unlike most of the games, you can't just walk behind a enemy and grab them, you have to gradually get slower until it prompts you to grab them, but this can f**k you over cause it doesn't tell you very much about the monitor. But I must admit, for it's problems I can forgive it, I...LOVE REALISM IN STEALTH GAMES! I am not a big fan of the cartoony stealth like "stealth ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s" or...well you get me. I like realistic stealth games where you are in situations that can mimic real life. This game does that almost perfectly, I guess this game i- I am getting off track. Stealth = 8/10STORYNow the story takes you through a bunch of locations ranging from a  Hokkaido Island (a dojo) to a giant ship( Maria Narcissa) and even Seoul, but no one likes the Seoul mission...The story is quite enjoyable if a bit cliche'ed but it does take you to some nice locations. story = 6/10.HOW DOES IT COMPARE TO NEWER SPINTER CELLSI've always found the new spinter cell odd, they changed so much. I felt and think they changed devs or engines, probably both. But I've always thought of conviction and blacklist as different games. They are great themselves it's just if you WANT a STEALTH game then choose this game. The newer ones are more likes AC, if you have someone in your way you kill them, but if you want a "stealth" game then you go for the ones that make you think about your decisions. If I kill this guy will anyone see it? Will I be able to move the body in time? Will anyone hear him drop? Those are the type of stealth games that in my opinion, represent the stealth genre greatly. How does the game fair? 8/10FINAL THOUGHTTom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory is a great stealth game. If you are a die-hard fan of stealth then you should have this game. Yes the FMV is cheesy but this is a game that was made in 2006, I don't blame it, and you shouldn't either. But for my final thought, this game is a underrated gem of the series, I find it a guilty pleasure, and from the reviews I see this is a very loved game. Pick it up, please, if you don't like it then just refund it.Tom Clancy's Splinter cell: Chaos Theory (I am saying Tom Clancy too much) get's my final rating of 8/10, a great game! If you enjoyed this review then leave a comment on my profile saying "+rep decent reviewer" it will make me happy <3

												This is a great stealth game. It's basically more of the first games, with less bugs and a sound detection bar. It's just weird that there's an "Assault" option for loadouts, as going in guns blazing will ruin the game completely. The most enjoyable way to play it is by trying to stay unseen and taking out only the guys standing directly in your way to the objective (IMHO). Changing your speed with the scrollwheel is a neat mechanic that I liked about this game. So is the alt-fire on the pistol that disabled electronics (so that you don't have to shoot them anymore).It has a great soundtrack that changes every level and as you get spotted or identified.Oh, there's plot too, mainly so that the missions don't all appear the same.This brings me to the less enjoyable part of the game: the repetition. Pretty much all you do is sneak around people or lure them till you can get behind them and snatch them. This made it very hard to play the game for longer than an hour at once, and I became pretty bored of it nearing the end. Some more ways of getting the information you need or getting people out of your way would be cool. The airfoil rounds, sticky shockers and gas grenades are supposed to do that job, but they all work in pretty much the same way. I guess this game could just use a little less linear gameplay is what I'm getting at.This game is definitely worth your time though, even ten years after release.

												The best video game I have ever played hands down. I have played through this countless times. It's perfect in every way and form. The solo campaign is lengthy with plenty of variety in environments. You'll sneak around cargo ships, apartmetns in NYC, and Japanese villages as the ultimate spy. Chaos Theory offers vast amounts of options for every level ensuring plenty of replay value. The graphics, while obviously old, still hold up pretty well to todays standards; with reflective surfaces, lots of realistic textures, and an AI system that is so much fun to mess with. The music, written by Amon Tobin, is fantastic and some of the best original soundtrack work for a video game I've heard. This is a game that you just NEED TO PLAY!The coop mode was amazing when it was working. It was at least 6 more missions that you could play with a friend and there were even some unique abilities you could do with your partner, like throwing him/her across hallways to knock out guards, or climbing them like a human ladder to get into higher windows. The servers aren't available anymore as far as I know, but I'm sure if you try and host one with your friend you should still be able to play it. The versus mode is a totally seperate game that's very creative and loads of fun. However! Be warned, this game is highly competitive and the players that are still playing online know the maps inside and out. It's best to play this mode with your friends until you get good enough to play against the 6 or so players that are still playing this online. Also, since the game's versus mode runs on an old engine, the lighting doesn't work anymore with new Nvidia video cards. There Is a fix if you go into the steam communtiy hub to fix it, but if you don't do this, the mercenaries flashlights won't work; which is not good considering you need the flashlight to see in the dark to find spies. Anyway, this game is a must play for anyone who's ever even had the slightest interest in video games... and considering you're reading this on "Steam", I'm almost positive you have some interest in video games yourself. So buy this game.. now.

												"Damn it Fisher". The only good Splinter Cell game. Or at least the only one that's memorable or some what worthwhile. Chaos Theroy is both over rated and severly dated (Coming from someone who grew up with far older titles I think that says something) and if your wondering if you should buy the game you might notice that all the positive reviews say it's great without explaining why. The story is a Call of Duty esque snore and the stealth is simplistic and boring but I must reluctantly say since there's a lot of freedom in how you deal with enemies (Kill or do not kill) or for how you can screw up it's still a video game (Take that for what you will).The AI springs between aimbot accuracy, sloth like, and just plain blind and or stupid. Unlike the console versions you can actually see whats going on as the PS2 and original Xbox version suffer from pitch blackness gamma syndrome even with the goggles or turning up your TV's brightness settings all the way. The graphics get the job done in regards to the world but the character models are frankly attrocious and suffer from pre next gen Ubisoft graphics with the enemy models looking especially bad (Barely better than Max Payne's) what with their mouths being green. The character models and blurry badly animated CGI make the game look even older than most PS2 games. Hell for 2005 it wasn't even the best stealth game. I think that title goes to Metal Gear Solid 3: Subsistance which was the re release of the 2004 original on weaker hardware that added a free thirdperson camera which is embarrassing considering that this Splinter Cell has better hardware than MGS 3 to work with on the Gamecube and Xbox Original and of course the PC.The real issue is it's terrible controls and awkward bindings for mouse and keyboard. The console controls were already wonky (And thats coming from someone who's used tank controls, pressure sensitive controls and motion controls.) but here on the PC both options control as if you were drunk. It's controls are harder to understand and get a grip on than any of the Arma titles and yes that extends to Operation Flashpoint/Cold War Assault. You name it and it will probably control better than Chaos Theroy (Middle mouse to aim, shft to jump?). At least you can rebind some of the conrols (The mouse wheel effecting your speed is interesting albiet flawed). If your excuse is "bad controls incentivise sneaking or avoiding combat" than every stealth game prior or afterwards would like to have a word with you.It's a mediocre third person shooter disguised as a stealth game with that aspect only just barely being above average and with the latter being primarily in focus. It's voice acting, music, level design, COOP and lack of Uplay are the only thing that salvages it from being total♥♥♥♥♥♥in my eyes. Even then the COOP is capped at 35 FPS for some bizarre reason and its hard to even get it working. If you like scanning crates and bad spanish accents this is the game for you. If you like stealth try anything else (Might I suggest Hitman: Blood Money or Theif?).I don't usually do numbered score but I give Splinter Cell: Chaos Theroy a 3/5 or a 4 out of 10.
